What is JSON Web Token?

## 

<span key="d9853868f9c746bbaf790e72ee3fef66"><span offset-key="d9853868f9c746bbaf790e72ee3fef66:0">What is JSON Web Token?</span></span>

<span key="a78cf1b4e4bd4515a46f2b31efd5839e"><span offset-key="a78cf1b4e4bd4515a46f2b31efd5839e:0">JSON Web Token (JWT) is an open standard (</span></span><a href="https://tools.ietf.org/html/rfc7519" class="css-4rbku5 css-1dbjc4n r-1loqt21 r-1471scf r-1otgn73 r-1i6wzkk r-lrvibr"><span data-key="1f9eab5bcceb4272b017bceea4f24da5" data-rnw-int-class="nearest_257-1697_259-1698-237__"><span data-key="96b51c150b9f44218352a8e17ad3f758"><span data-offset-key="96b51c150b9f44218352a8e17ad3f758:0">RFC 7519</span></span></span></a><span key="ebc7b0b7b88f47fc8ee819df93dab169"><span offset-key="ebc7b0b7b88f47fc8ee819df93dab169:0">) that defines a compact and self-contained way for securely transmitting information between parties as a JSON object. This information can be verified and trusted because it is digitally signed. JWTs can be signed using a secret (with the </span>**HMAC**<span offset-key="ebc7b0b7b88f47fc8ee819df93dab169:2"> algorithm) or a public/private key pair using </span>**RSA**<span offset-key="ebc7b0b7b88f47fc8ee819df93dab169:4"> or </span>**ECDSA**<span offset-key="ebc7b0b7b88f47fc8ee819df93dab169:6">.</span></span>

<span key="a584859ff7064efbb226eb20aca24509"><span offset-key="a584859ff7064efbb226eb20aca24509:0"><span slate-zero-width="n">â€‹</span></span></span>

1.  <span class="r-1awozwy r-1nf4jbm r-6koalj r-18u37iz r-gg6oyi r-ubezar r-16dba41 r-135wba7 r-1m04atk r-1pyaxff" contenteditable="false" style="height:24px">1.</span>
    <span key="6dc8266a81904b3dab8590d8cd2f628d"><span offset-key="6dc8266a81904b3dab8590d8cd2f628d:0">JSON Web Token (JWT) Overview</span></span>

<span key="1f2438ee6856494fb8824bb55f231476"><span offset-key="1f2438ee6856494fb8824bb55f231476:0">JWTs represent a set of claims as a JSON object that is encoded in a JWS and/or JWE structure. This JSON object is the JWT Claims Set. As per Section 4 of RFC 7159 \[RFC7159\], the JSON object consists of zero or more name/value pairs (or members), where the names are strings and the values are arbitrary JSON values. These members are the claims represented by the JWT. This JSON object MAY contain whitespace and/or line breaks before or after any JSON values or structural characters, in accordance with Section 2 of RFC 7159 \[RFC7159\].</span></span>

<span key="d7d1f62a2ee1455fb9021f7310935ecf"><span offset-key="d7d1f62a2ee1455fb9021f7310935ecf:0">The member names within the JWT Claims Set are referred to as Claim Names. The corresponding values are referred to as Claim Values.</span></span>

<span key="c79fe059c3904359a36e71b37f88958f"><span offset-key="c79fe059c3904359a36e71b37f88958f:0">The contents of the JOSE Header describe the cryptographic operations applied to the JWT Claims Set. If the JOSE Header is for a JWS, the JWT is represented as a JWS and the claims are digitally signed or MACed, with the JWT Claims Set being the JWS Payload. If the JOSE Header is for a JWE, the JWT is represented as a JWE and the claims are encrypted, with the JWT Claims Set being the plaintext encrypted by the JWE. A JWT may be enclosed in another JWE or JWS structure to create a Nested JWT, enabling nested signing and encryption to be performed.</span></span>

<span key="9fcfcbc7523c447f9ecd5fccf59fe503"><span offset-key="9fcfcbc7523c447f9ecd5fccf59fe503:0">A JWT is represented as a sequence of URL-safe parts separated by period ('.') characters. Each part contains a base64url-encoded value. The number of parts in the JWT is dependent upon the representation of the resulting JWS using the JWS Compact Serialization or JWE using the JWE Compact Serialization.</span></span>

<span key="739dff72a19e4e07b6d93bd24b66dfee"><span offset-key="739dff72a19e4e07b6d93bd24b66dfee:0">Jones, et al. Standards Track \[Page 6\]</span></span>

<span key="8141f8fe62564ba2bd476495ea1e2738"><span offset-key="8141f8fe62564ba2bd476495ea1e2738:0">RFC 7519 JSON Web Token (JWT) May 2015</span></span>

<span key="d7d2af8c8dc345f2baa375f5be41253a"><span offset-key="d7d2af8c8dc345f2baa375f5be41253a:0">3.1. Example JWT</span></span>

<span key="3124305dfef2495e8fd8c6dae51b1cdc"><span offset-key="3124305dfef2495e8fd8c6dae51b1cdc:0">The following example JOSE Header declares that the encoded object is a JWT, and the JWT is a JWS that is MACed using the HMAC SHA-256 algorithm:</span></span>

1

<span key="716d6ca1b59a4e5a9e80bc56f4d6ca8b"><span offset-key="716d6ca1b59a4e5a9e80bc56f4d6ca8b:0"> {"typ":"JWT",</span></span>

2

<span key="2cbd74666c6a4911954093c09b89afda"><span offset-key="2cbd74666c6a4911954093c09b89afda:0"> "alg":"HS256"}</span></span>

<img src="data:image/svg+xml;base64," class="r-h7gdob r-10ptun7" />

Copied!

<span key="8794172aca3e42bbabdb806e56ccd170"><span offset-key="8794172aca3e42bbabdb806e56ccd170:0">To remove potential ambiguities in the representation of the JSON object above, the octet sequence for the actual UTF-8 representation used in this example for the JOSE Header above is also included below. (Note that ambiguities can arise due to differing platform representations of line breaks (CRLF versus LF), differing spacing at the beginning and ends of lines, whether the last line has a terminating line break or not, and other causes. In the representation used in this example, the first line has no leading or trailing spaces, a CRLF line break (13, 10) occurs between the first and second lines, the second line has one leading space (32) and no trailing spaces, and the last line does not have a terminating line break.) The octets representing the UTF-8 representation of the JOSE Header in this example (using JSON array notation) are:</span></span>

<span key="b4357ab0fc41419b846c425b46115963"><span offset-key="b4357ab0fc41419b846c425b46115963:0">\[123, 34, 116, 121, 112, 34, 58, 34, 74, 87, 84, 34, 44, 13, 10, 32, 34, 97, 108, 103, 34, 58, 34, 72, 83, 50, 53, 54, 34, 125\]</span></span>

<span key="8093e91fec5d46d5baf6dc171eec654d"><span offset-key="8093e91fec5d46d5baf6dc171eec654d:0">Base64url encoding the octets of the UTF-8 representation of the JOSE Header yields this encoded JOSE Header value:</span></span>

1

<span key="6f89f008613e40a894f9bb634afdf173"><span offset-key="6f89f008613e40a894f9bb634afdf173:0"> eyJ0eXAiOiJKV1QiLA0KICJhbGciOiJIUzI1NiJ9</span></span>

<img src="data:image/svg+xml;base64," class="r-h7gdob r-10ptun7 r-1vzi8xi" />

Copied!

<span key="5d5e4bcb16ce46e8a34ecc524e3a1ca1"><span offset-key="5d5e4bcb16ce46e8a34ecc524e3a1ca1:0">The following is an example of a JWT Claims Set:</span></span>

1

<span key="be46fded6fa343eda589a4b34fef362e"><span offset-key="be46fded6fa343eda589a4b34fef362e:0"> {"iss":"joe",</span></span>

2

<span key="41c9e7e4766f41b1bf6b0c3f253e6718"><span offset-key="41c9e7e4766f41b1bf6b0c3f253e6718:0"> "exp":1300819380,</span></span>

3

<span key="e28e2b332417485896b08ec5137e6c1e"><span offset-key="e28e2b332417485896b08ec5137e6c1e:0"> "http://example.com/is\_root":true}</span></span>

<img src="data:image/svg+xml;base64," class="r-h7gdob r-10ptun7 r-1vzi8xi" />

Copied!

<span key="3c0afd31fe084fb884acf71be2500f89"><span offset-key="3c0afd31fe084fb884acf71be2500f89:0">The following octet sequence, which is the UTF-8 representation used in this example for the JWT Claims Set above, is the JWS Payload:</span></span>

<span key="26adecd1ccfe4a34bec86dbf514d70b8"><span offset-key="26adecd1ccfe4a34bec86dbf514d70b8:0">\[123, 34, 105, 115, 115, 34, 58, 34, 106, 111, 101, 34, 44, 13, 10, 32, 34, 101, 120, 112, 34, 58, 49, 51, 48, 48, 56, 49, 57, 51, 56, 48, 44, 13, 10, 32, 34, 104, 116, 116, 112, 58, 47, 47, 101, 120, 97, 109, 112, 108, 101, 46, 99, 111, 109, 47, 105, 115, 95, 114, 111, 111, 116, 34, 58, 116, 114, 117, 101, 125\]</span></span>

<span key="74f42859e13b43db9270b00806fba9cd"><span offset-key="74f42859e13b43db9270b00806fba9cd:0"><span slate-zero-width="n">â€‹</span></span></span>

<span key="7d000718a7154c269c06962a486e6990"><span offset-key="7d000718a7154c269c06962a486e6990:0">Although JWTs can be encrypted to also provide secrecy between parties, we will focus on </span>*signed*<span offset-key="7d000718a7154c269c06962a486e6990:2"> tokens. Signed tokens can verify the </span>*integrity*<span offset-key="7d000718a7154c269c06962a486e6990:4"> of the claims contained within it, while encrypted tokens </span>*hide*<span offset-key="7d000718a7154c269c06962a486e6990:6"> those claims from other parties. When tokens are signed using public/private key pairs, the signature also certifies that only the party holding the private key is the one that signed it.</span></span>

## 

<span key="a74c8d4a36b3459ba164df4be9e37693"><span offset-key="a74c8d4a36b3459ba164df4be9e37693:0">When should you use JSON Web Tokens?</span></span>

<span key="d7f5b7a58e0448c180313e483f359e34"><span offset-key="d7f5b7a58e0448c180313e483f359e34:0">Here are some scenarios where JSON Web Tokens are useful:</span></span>

-   <img src="data:image/svg+xml;base64," class="r-1nf4jbm r-1vzi8xi" />

    <span key="bd80f0585398487d8577295495c44d75">**Authorization**<span offset-key="bd80f0585398487d8577295495c44d75:1">: This is the most common scenario for using JWT. Once the user is logged in, each subsequent request will include the JWT, allowing the user to access routes, services, and resources that are permitted with that token. Single Sign On is a feature that widely uses JWT nowadays, because of its small overhead and its ability to be easily used across different domains.</span></span>

-   <img src="data:image/svg+xml;base64," class="r-1nf4jbm r-1vzi8xi" />

    <span key="521f0b0749544806b4c2e8f890859177">**Information Exchange**<span offset-key="521f0b0749544806b4c2e8f890859177:1">: JSON Web Tokens are a good way of securely transmitting information between parties. Because JWTs can be signedâ€”for example, using public/private key pairsâ€”you can be sure the senders are who they say they are. Additionally, as the signature is calculated using the header and the payload, you can also verify that the content hasn't been tampered with.</span></span>

## 

<span key="c280062381094ffaabb42944c2a98c43"><span offset-key="c280062381094ffaabb42944c2a98c43:0">What is the JSON Web Token structure?</span></span>

<span key="0a320f7b7c944932af97239a04c415bf"><span offset-key="0a320f7b7c944932af97239a04c415bf:0">In its compact form, JSON Web Tokens consist of three parts separated by dots (</span>`.`<span offset-key="0a320f7b7c944932af97239a04c415bf:2">), which are:</span></span>

-   <img src="data:image/svg+xml;base64," class="r-1nf4jbm r-1vzi8xi" />

    <span key="03c81433e3b14fc8a5b9d0299359eac3"><span offset-key="03c81433e3b14fc8a5b9d0299359eac3:0">Header</span></span>

-   <img src="data:image/svg+xml;base64," class="r-1nf4jbm r-1vzi8xi" />

    <span key="0e92bb074b4b4b60b7df2774581e95c7"><span offset-key="0e92bb074b4b4b60b7df2774581e95c7:0">Payload</span></span>

-   <img src="data:image/svg+xml;base64," class="r-1nf4jbm r-1vzi8xi" />

    <span key="dd2323585ce44fcc9e4d0985cd49cea3"><span offset-key="dd2323585ce44fcc9e4d0985cd49cea3:0">Signature</span></span>

<span key="cf086f6b773843fca62850de7c5628e1"><span offset-key="cf086f6b773843fca62850de7c5628e1:0">Therefore, a JWT typically looks like the following.</span></span>

<span key="534492bd5e214fc8892d4951daca6db0">`xxxxx.yyyyy.zzzzz`</span>

<span key="dda3844edaa14e91b52335ae3aa1abfc"><span offset-key="dda3844edaa14e91b52335ae3aa1abfc:0">Let's break down the different parts.</span></span>

### 

<span key="bdf9797e1c884b96b76de8bb4145fd27"><span offset-key="bdf9797e1c884b96b76de8bb4145fd27:0">Header</span></span>

<span key="a8923ee9647e4ecaacd54763ac01aec9"><span offset-key="a8923ee9647e4ecaacd54763ac01aec9:0">The header </span>*typically*<span offset-key="a8923ee9647e4ecaacd54763ac01aec9:2"> consists of two parts: the type of the token, which is JWT, and the signing algorithm being used, such as HMAC SHA256 or RSA.</span></span>

<span key="0a1e619b92a14bb4a55949c01a039ce4"><span offset-key="0a1e619b92a14bb4a55949c01a039ce4:0">For example:</span></span>

1

<span key="13de55d89e8b4ceea5a1ebb223c7806f"><span offset-key="13de55d89e8b4ceea5a1ebb223c7806f:0">{</span></span>

2

<span key="6ab1ce026d49489c9ac8543ae2296666"><span offset-key="6ab1ce026d49489c9ac8543ae2296666:0"> "alg": "HS256",</span></span>

3

<span key="0de0cfafbc6941cba0e45903c67b3747"><span offset-key="0de0cfafbc6941cba0e45903c67b3747:0"> "typ": "JWT"</span></span>

4

<span key="d4fa4f9e119642a2bcd220b9fa521dee"><span offset-key="d4fa4f9e119642a2bcd220b9fa521dee:0">}</span></span>

<img src="data:image/svg+xml;base64," class="r-h7gdob r-10ptun7 r-1vzi8xi" />

Copied!

<span key="0a68ad3ba2e34dd39950091a6cfd2343"><span offset-key="0a68ad3ba2e34dd39950091a6cfd2343:0">Then, this JSON is </span>**Base64Url**<span offset-key="0a68ad3ba2e34dd39950091a6cfd2343:2"> encoded to form the first part of the JWT.</span></span>

### 

<span key="1e7cdea8aa1c47898e8e0a5461034ea8"><span offset-key="1e7cdea8aa1c47898e8e0a5461034ea8:0">Payload</span></span>

<span key="da7bfee687744bdbb5b0c9f7b56d4366"><span offset-key="da7bfee687744bdbb5b0c9f7b56d4366:0">The second part of the token is the payload, which contains the claims. Claims are statements about an entity (typically, the user) and additional data. There are three types of claims: </span>*registered*<span offset-key="da7bfee687744bdbb5b0c9f7b56d4366:2">, </span>*public*<span offset-key="da7bfee687744bdbb5b0c9f7b56d4366:4">, and </span>*private*<span offset-key="da7bfee687744bdbb5b0c9f7b56d4366:6"> claims.</span></span>

-   <img src="data:image/svg+xml;base64," class="r-1nf4jbm r-1vzi8xi" />

    <span key="12a425e0adad4f79b02ec8f21409e44a"><span offset-key="12a425e0adad4f79b02ec8f21409e44a:0"><span slate-zero-width="z">â€‹</span></span></span><a href="https://tools.ietf.org/html/rfc7519#section-4.1" class="css-4rbku5 css-1dbjc4n r-1loqt21 r-1471scf r-1otgn73 r-1i6wzkk r-lrvibr"><span data-key="5a26996fb25b45f98b7a8284dfe88a43" data-rnw-int-class="nearest_257-1697_259-1698-237__"><span data-key="41c0a606b602422abb728dc7e0696df4"><strong>Registered claims</strong></span></span></a><span key="4709f297fab6493e8bf43ae6815e08e9"><span offset-key="4709f297fab6493e8bf43ae6815e08e9:0">: These are a set of predefined claims which are not mandatory but recommended, to provide a set of useful, interoperable claims. Some of them are: </span>**iss**<span offset-key="4709f297fab6493e8bf43ae6815e08e9:2"> (issuer), </span>**exp**<span offset-key="4709f297fab6493e8bf43ae6815e08e9:4"> (expiration time), </span>**sub**<span offset-key="4709f297fab6493e8bf43ae6815e08e9:6"> (subject), </span>**aud**<span offset-key="4709f297fab6493e8bf43ae6815e08e9:8"> (audience), and </span></span><a href="https://tools.ietf.org/html/rfc7519#section-4.1" class="css-4rbku5 css-1dbjc4n r-1loqt21 r-1471scf r-1otgn73 r-1i6wzkk r-lrvibr"><span data-key="addb5687078343f791e78cd0174a5b6e" data-rnw-int-class="nearest_257-1697_259-1698-237__"><span data-key="9d2a7dcd500f4b97bebf01abd1e3a5c7"><span data-offset-key="9d2a7dcd500f4b97bebf01abd1e3a5c7:0">others</span></span></span></a><span key="4544512dd9e14ba5aeac0e1ce60a7df8"><span offset-key="4544512dd9e14ba5aeac0e1ce60a7df8:0">.</span></span>

    > <span key="25c249d131314774891441bb7d9294cb"><span offset-key="25c249d131314774891441bb7d9294cb:0">Notice that the claim names are only three characters long as JWT is meant to be compact.</span></span>

-   <img src="data:image/svg+xml;base64," class="r-1nf4jbm r-1vzi8xi" />

    <span key="f2c29a6b2539417f9a33d52b3a2e431a"><span offset-key="f2c29a6b2539417f9a33d52b3a2e431a:0"><span slate-zero-width="z">â€‹</span></span></span><a href="https://tools.ietf.org/html/rfc7519#section-4.2" class="css-4rbku5 css-1dbjc4n r-1loqt21 r-1471scf r-1otgn73 r-1i6wzkk r-lrvibr"><span data-key="765d88d492114c5c867708460f2052d5" data-rnw-int-class="nearest_257-1697_259-1698-237__"><span data-key="0a0b673694cd417385152f0fda82b92f"><strong>Public claims</strong></span></span></a><span key="81ec3ef0d70344f0b17ae6fffba59a20"><span offset-key="81ec3ef0d70344f0b17ae6fffba59a20:0">: These can be defined at will by those using JWTs. But to avoid collisions they should be defined in the </span></span><a href="https://www.iana.org/assignments/jwt/jwt.xhtml" class="css-4rbku5 css-1dbjc4n r-1loqt21 r-1471scf r-1otgn73 r-1i6wzkk r-lrvibr"><span data-key="5f0201f52ff44e7e88ee6e6f05c10a2f" data-rnw-int-class="nearest_257-1697_259-1698-237__"><span data-key="d7e842d8adb648418e80824a94f7e08a"><span data-offset-key="d7e842d8adb648418e80824a94f7e08a:0">IANA JSON Web Token Registry</span></span></span></a><span key="c101b097c0fd4a7f9ea5f45090e7e06e"><span offset-key="c101b097c0fd4a7f9ea5f45090e7e06e:0"> or be defined as a URI that contains a collision resistant namespace.</span></span>

-   <img src="data:image/svg+xml;base64," class="r-1nf4jbm r-1vzi8xi" />

    <span key="6262c315b89048e6b7bec9b3afdeadb8"><span offset-key="6262c315b89048e6b7bec9b3afdeadb8:0"><span slate-zero-width="z">â€‹</span></span></span><a href="https://tools.ietf.org/html/rfc7519#section-4.3" class="css-4rbku5 css-1dbjc4n r-1loqt21 r-1471scf r-1otgn73 r-1i6wzkk r-lrvibr"><span data-key="9fb253bb0fff4d42be223cf7970542cc" data-rnw-int-class="nearest_257-1697_259-1698-237__"><span data-key="f73ea7161c964c1a8ebd69f33f761edc"><strong>Private claims</strong></span></span></a><span key="78f4b92407364edfaa9e2c78e8a33d20"><span offset-key="78f4b92407364edfaa9e2c78e8a33d20:0">: These are the custom claims created to share information between parties that agree on using them and are neither </span>*registered*<span offset-key="78f4b92407364edfaa9e2c78e8a33d20:2"> or </span>*public*<span offset-key="78f4b92407364edfaa9e2c78e8a33d20:4"> claims.</span></span>

<span key="5bb81ea48a4c4f73b780b9a07e69a4ff"><span offset-key="5bb81ea48a4c4f73b780b9a07e69a4ff:0">An example payload could be:</span></span>

1

<span key="cbd480895a2d400982933b2e4e36ed34"><span offset-key="cbd480895a2d400982933b2e4e36ed34:0">{</span></span>

2

<span key="b28801d8657e4f9b9c56393d85f7cb27"><span offset-key="b28801d8657e4f9b9c56393d85f7cb27:0"> "sub": "1234567890",</span></span>

3

<span key="abfa28a7e61c42d2b880b1e060734b48"><span offset-key="abfa28a7e61c42d2b880b1e060734b48:0"> "name": "John Doe",</span></span>

4

<span key="937cbcb3a98b4679baab321bc3eb6217"><span offset-key="937cbcb3a98b4679baab321bc3eb6217:0"> "admin": true</span></span>

5

<span key="ad0d7a6edbfb4d2eb65a7807646cc334"><span offset-key="ad0d7a6edbfb4d2eb65a7807646cc334:0">}</span></span>

<img src="data:image/svg+xml;base64," class="r-h7gdob r-10ptun7 r-1vzi8xi" />

Copied!

<span key="88783cfaa2f74dcd8d379dc74162c232"><span offset-key="88783cfaa2f74dcd8d379dc74162c232:0">The payload is then </span>**Base64Url**<span offset-key="88783cfaa2f74dcd8d379dc74162c232:2"> encoded to form the second part of the JSON Web Token.</span></span>

> <span key="2c6f812fa8c9457ba6f5927fac74e207"><span offset-key="2c6f812fa8c9457ba6f5927fac74e207:0">Do note that for signed tokens this information, though protected against tampering, is readable by anyone. Do not put secret information in the payload or header elements of a JWT unless it is encrypted.</span></span>

### 

<span key="ee746ef71fbc4de6b0209297a0aa630c"><span offset-key="ee746ef71fbc4de6b0209297a0aa630c:0">Signature</span></span>

<span key="ada2cb54675049af8241826a04dd9bfd"><span offset-key="ada2cb54675049af8241826a04dd9bfd:0">To create the signature part you have to take the encoded header, the encoded payload, a secret, the algorithm specified in the header, and sign that.</span></span>

<span key="0ace5b2c041e41ba947b7484d3f36e24"><span offset-key="0ace5b2c041e41ba947b7484d3f36e24:0">For example if you want to use the HMAC SHA256 algorithm, the signature will be created in the following way:</span></span>

1

<span key="2fcb40a576ea4ccb9ffd566b48149ed2"><span offset-key="2fcb40a576ea4ccb9ffd566b48149ed2:0">HMACSHA256(</span></span>

2

<span key="3dd0b6aae6774d2b8466aaf6702ddfcb"><span offset-key="3dd0b6aae6774d2b8466aaf6702ddfcb:0"> base64UrlEncode(header) + "." +</span></span>

3

<span key="8148ba23ce034e8eb22c9ad8283c7b95"><span offset-key="8148ba23ce034e8eb22c9ad8283c7b95:0"> base64UrlEncode(payload),</span></span>

4

<span key="7a02a531ab9f470c8a987883ce9b8ea6"><span offset-key="7a02a531ab9f470c8a987883ce9b8ea6:0"> secret)</span></span>

<img src="data:image/svg+xml;base64," class="r-h7gdob r-10ptun7 r-1vzi8xi" />

Copied!

<span key="a67390c471fa43b0bbc3f80253b2dc63"><span offset-key="a67390c471fa43b0bbc3f80253b2dc63:0">The signature is used to verify the message wasn't changed along the way, and, in the case of tokens signed with a private key, it can also verify that the sender of the JWT is who it says it is.</span></span>

### 

<span key="8819f4c9e6d947809c62c291063cdc10"><span offset-key="8819f4c9e6d947809c62c291063cdc10:0">Putting all together</span></span>

<span key="0dcfd8a06b294a86beb6032edff5088c"><span offset-key="0dcfd8a06b294a86beb6032edff5088c:0">The output is three Base64-URL strings separated by dots that can be easily passed in HTML and HTTP environments, while being more compact when compared to XML-based standards such as SAML.</span></span>

<span key="8934327508bc473fbfacbdb7c25721f8"><span offset-key="8934327508bc473fbfacbdb7c25721f8:0">The following shows a JWT that has the previous header and payload encoded, and it is signed with a secret. </span></span>

<span key="11c2282bae494f5fbf677c5c31a03a31"><span offset-key="11c2282bae494f5fbf677c5c31a03a31:0">If you want to play with JWT and put these concepts into practice, you can use </span></span><a href="https://jwt.io/#debugger-io" class="css-4rbku5 css-1dbjc4n r-1loqt21 r-1471scf r-1otgn73 r-1i6wzkk r-lrvibr"><span data-key="4eb9d338c6ae4526809bd29cb768f5d9" data-rnw-int-class="nearest_257-1697_259-1698-237__"><span data-key="a7400497816140fe913312e303210f5b"><span data-offset-key="a7400497816140fe913312e303210f5b:0">jwt.io Debugger</span></span></span></a><span key="f6fd9f68306a4d50a3b357d357c0aba6"><span offset-key="f6fd9f68306a4d50a3b357d357c0aba6:0"> to decode, verify, and generate JWTs.</span></span>

<span key="45a8587b93af48f7b1507764e4d58b47"><span offset-key="45a8587b93af48f7b1507764e4d58b47:0">JWT.io Debugger</span></span>

## 

<span key="949a5cfeb98945838a31b2b44c615cc3"><span offset-key="949a5cfeb98945838a31b2b44c615cc3:0">How do JSON Web Tokens work?</span></span>

<span key="143fc9b3fe33495ca1f25f67edc9ad81"><span offset-key="143fc9b3fe33495ca1f25f67edc9ad81:0">In authentication, when the user successfully logs in using their credentials, a JSON Web Token will be returned. Since tokens are credentials, great care must be taken to prevent security issues. In general, you should not keep tokens longer than required.</span></span>

<span key="5c7bafb58e0c4d9aac39c148b2431ff5"><span offset-key="5c7bafb58e0c4d9aac39c148b2431ff5:0">You also </span></span><a href="https://cheatsheetseries.owasp.org/cheatsheets/HTML5_Security_Cheat_Sheet.html#local-storage" class="css-4rbku5 css-1dbjc4n r-1loqt21 r-1471scf r-1otgn73 r-1i6wzkk r-lrvibr"><span data-key="96f570e52d884213883276973ad6d2a1" data-rnw-int-class="nearest_257-1697_259-1698-237__"><span data-key="3d935288604446c590638aad5d3cad67"><span data-offset-key="3d935288604446c590638aad5d3cad67:0">should not store sensitive session data in browser storage due to lack of security</span></span></span></a><span key="f497812035944f87b0cc3ce99abca1b0"><span offset-key="f497812035944f87b0cc3ce99abca1b0:0">.</span></span>

<span key="b465602cc00846ebb580a7272eb05384"><span offset-key="b465602cc00846ebb580a7272eb05384:0">Whenever the user wants to access a protected route or resource, the user agent should send the JWT, typically in the </span>**Authorization**<span offset-key="b465602cc00846ebb580a7272eb05384:2"> header using the </span>**Bearer**<span offset-key="b465602cc00846ebb580a7272eb05384:4"> schema. The content of the header should look like the following:</span></span>

1

<span key="e22551f788f84913a4a9af9793c8c2bd"><span offset-key="e22551f788f84913a4a9af9793c8c2bd:0">Authorization: Bearer &lt;token></span></span>

<img src="data:image/svg+xml;base64," class="r-h7gdob r-10ptun7 r-1vzi8xi" />

Copied!

<span key="ab7d7f1b52e14812b8b5e6b4e5154f10"><span offset-key="ab7d7f1b52e14812b8b5e6b4e5154f10:0">This can be, in certain cases, a stateless authorization mechanism. The server's protected routes will check for a valid JWT in the </span>`Authorization`<span offset-key="ab7d7f1b52e14812b8b5e6b4e5154f10:2"> header, and if it's present, the user will be allowed to access protected resources. If the JWT contains the necessary data, the need to query the database for certain operations may be reduced, though this may not always be the case.</span></span>

<span key="d17e6d2c846e495bae9a54e32d274a5f"><span offset-key="d17e6d2c846e495bae9a54e32d274a5f:0">If the token is sent in the </span>`Authorization`<span offset-key="d17e6d2c846e495bae9a54e32d274a5f:2"> header, Cross-Origin Resource Sharing (CORS) won't be an issue as it doesn't use cookies.</span></span>

<span key="c295a7322e9d4163b00e8e769d25f7d9"><span offset-key="c295a7322e9d4163b00e8e769d25f7d9:0">The following diagram shows how a JWT is obtained and used to access APIs or resources:</span></span>

<span key="4a960e77b4fd42e8a73008c1b249da7b"><span offset-key="4a960e77b4fd42e8a73008c1b249da7b:0">How does a JSON Web Token work</span></span>

1.  <span class="r-1awozwy r-1nf4jbm r-6koalj r-18u37iz r-gg6oyi r-ubezar r-16dba41 r-135wba7 r-1m04atk r-1pyaxff" contenteditable="false" style="height:24px">1.</span>
    <span key="7dd10acdad9349b1afaa9694e14ec19c"><span offset-key="7dd10acdad9349b1afaa9694e14ec19c:0">The application or client requests authorization to the authorization server. This is performed through one of the different authorization flows. For example, a typical </span></span><a href="http://openid.net/connect/" class="css-4rbku5 css-1dbjc4n r-1loqt21 r-1471scf r-1otgn73 r-1i6wzkk r-lrvibr"><span data-key="b38cdc240e734686b41a49d6776736c1" data-rnw-int-class="nearest_257-1697_259-1698-237__"><span data-key="ffecf082bd354cb081cd5e878ec822d3"><span data-offset-key="ffecf082bd354cb081cd5e878ec822d3:0">OpenID Connect</span></span></span></a><span key="43551185aedd45b9a39b9d9cd11dc78c"><span offset-key="43551185aedd45b9a39b9d9cd11dc78c:0"> compliant web application will go through the </span>`/oauth/authorize`<span offset-key="43551185aedd45b9a39b9d9cd11dc78c:2"> endpoint using the </span></span><a href="http://openid.net/specs/openid-connect-core-1_0.html#CodeFlowAuth" class="css-4rbku5 css-1dbjc4n r-1loqt21 r-1471scf r-1otgn73 r-1i6wzkk r-lrvibr"><span data-key="ecab8e25462d48509934a647292a77c8" data-rnw-int-class="nearest_257-1697_259-1698-237__"><span data-key="c576bb7a254940c6ada25577de2a957c"><span data-offset-key="c576bb7a254940c6ada25577de2a957c:0">authorization code flow</span></span></span></a><span key="fb25a8a7b24c480084b9553fe2763dd1"><span offset-key="fb25a8a7b24c480084b9553fe2763dd1:0">.</span></span>

2.  <span class="r-1awozwy r-1nf4jbm r-6koalj r-18u37iz r-gg6oyi r-ubezar r-16dba41 r-135wba7 r-1m04atk r-1pyaxff" contenteditable="false" style="height:24px">2.</span>
    <span key="0da3decfd32f48868e21ef295e27352f"><span offset-key="0da3decfd32f48868e21ef295e27352f:0">When the authorization is granted, the authorization server returns an access token to the application.</span></span>

3.  <span class="r-1awozwy r-1nf4jbm r-6koalj r-18u37iz r-gg6oyi r-ubezar r-16dba41 r-135wba7 r-1m04atk r-1pyaxff" contenteditable="false" style="height:24px">3.</span>
    <span key="961839cf71944110a148878b79141d2f"><span offset-key="961839cf71944110a148878b79141d2f:0">The application uses the access token to access a protected resource (like an API).</span></span>

<span key="897af88399864d739ff539bada54855e"><span offset-key="897af88399864d739ff539bada54855e:0">Do note that with signed tokens, all the information contained within the token is exposed to users or other parties, even though they are unable to change it. This means you should not put secret information within the token.</span></span>

## 

<span key="79fea0be80a94982813e3cc33e3fb0c1"><span offset-key="79fea0be80a94982813e3cc33e3fb0c1:0">Why should we use JSON Web Tokens?</span></span>

<span key="4394e17d41ca474490a8d8b9d3ae7822"><span offset-key="4394e17d41ca474490a8d8b9d3ae7822:0">Let's talk about the benefits of </span>**JSON Web Tokens (JWT)**<span offset-key="4394e17d41ca474490a8d8b9d3ae7822:2"> when compared to </span>**Simple Web Tokens (SWT)**<span offset-key="4394e17d41ca474490a8d8b9d3ae7822:4"> and </span>**Security Assertion Markup Language Tokens (SAML)**<span offset-key="4394e17d41ca474490a8d8b9d3ae7822:6">.</span></span>

<span key="00abee6086ad47a3aaf721ac899a5f03"><span offset-key="00abee6086ad47a3aaf721ac899a5f03:0">As JSON is less verbose than XML, when it is encoded its size is also smaller, making JWT more compact than SAML. This makes JWT a good choice to be passed in HTML and HTTP environments.</span></span>

<span key="cfff17fb358c4e7ea96569fcc1efe060"><span offset-key="cfff17fb358c4e7ea96569fcc1efe060:0">Security-wise, SWT can only be symmetrically signed by a shared secret using the HMAC algorithm. However, JWT and SAML tokens can use a public/private key pair in the form of a X.509 certificate for signing. Signing XML with XML Digital Signature without introducing obscure security holes is very difficult when compared to the simplicity of signing JSON.</span></span>

<span key="552f362f03c44731ae1b9e4669a06ded"><span offset-key="552f362f03c44731ae1b9e4669a06ded:0">JSON parsers are common in most programming languages because they map directly to objects. Conversely, XML doesn't have a natural document-to-object mapping. This makes it easier to work with JWT than SAML assertions.</span></span>

<span key="3099bb9676fb4553b4fbc1784055a6eb"><span offset-key="3099bb9676fb4553b4fbc1784055a6eb:0">Regarding usage, JWT is used at Internet scale. This highlights the ease of client-side processing of the JSON Web token on multiple platforms, especially mobile.</span></span>

<span key="b0e6ad0a327041e7943ea748e549de26"><span offset-key="b0e6ad0a327041e7943ea748e549de26:0"><span slate-zero-width="z">â€‹</span></span></span><span slate-void="true" key="d38752ca9b79480fb3c221d7bd59abbd"></span>

<span key="2c0ea0a647a44dd5a87510fddd13b786"><span offset-key="2c0ea0a647a44dd5a87510fddd13b786:0"> </span>*Comparison of the length of an encoded JWT and an encoded SAML*</span>

<span key="86b54f1f50204186a7bf7ad8b9d65376"><span offset-key="86b54f1f50204186a7bf7ad8b9d65376:0">If you want to read more about JSON Web Tokens and even start using them to perform authentication in your own applications, browse to the </span></span><a href="http://auth0.com/learn/json-web-tokens" class="css-4rbku5 css-1dbjc4n r-1loqt21 r-1471scf r-1otgn73 r-1i6wzkk r-lrvibr"><span data-key="6a19f102031f4411b17715e10774056c" data-rnw-int-class="nearest_257-1697_259-1698-237__"><span data-key="0a5138506bf043faba16a7d10f3b4504"><span data-offset-key="0a5138506bf043faba16a7d10f3b4504:0">JSON Web Token landing page</span></span></span></a><span key="6c4354fdfc0740478678deaf003387af"><span offset-key="6c4354fdfc0740478678deaf003387af:0"> at Auth0.</span></span>

<span key="5148f21048644a2eaaa47339cf3cb4c4"><span offset-key="5148f21048644a2eaaa47339cf3cb4c4:0"><span slate-zero-width="n">â€‹</span></span></span>

## 

<span key="c44fec70cac84c078c3cc5b1aabc5fdf"><span offset-key="c44fec70cac84c078c3cc5b1aabc5fdf:0">WHAT IS JSON WEB TOKEN?</span></span>

<span key="9f164587f76b4c9f95255c40625284df">**JSON Web Token (JWT)**<span offset-key="9f164587f76b4c9f95255c40625284df:1"> is an open standard (</span></span><a href="https://tools.ietf.org/html/rfc7519" class="css-4rbku5 css-1dbjc4n r-1loqt21 r-1471scf r-1otgn73 r-1i6wzkk r-lrvibr"><span data-key="71231e2b5c0e4df394806b88b480d6b0" data-rnw-int-class="nearest_257-1697_259-1698-237__"><span data-key="f7aa85796ed64bb581e6249e75e396d8"><span data-offset-key="f7aa85796ed64bb581e6249e75e396d8:0">RFC 7519</span></span></span></a><span key="11732b47e83d484989c6cf2a3f977814"><span offset-key="11732b47e83d484989c6cf2a3f977814:0">) that defines a compact and self-contained way for securely transmitting information between parties as a JSON object. This information can be verified and trusted because it is digitally signed. JWTs can be signed using a secret (with </span>**HMAC**<span offset-key="11732b47e83d484989c6cf2a3f977814:2"> algorithm) or a public/private key pair using </span>**RSA**<span offset-key="11732b47e83d484989c6cf2a3f977814:4">.</span></span>

<span key="4f438b4602e44cd98fbdeb0917657938"><span offset-key="4f438b4602e44cd98fbdeb0917657938:0">Letâ€™s explain some concepts of this definition further.</span></span>

-   <img src="data:image/svg+xml;base64," class="r-1nf4jbm r-1vzi8xi" />

    <span key="bc33566253704b16bef5bc7b6b805f58">**Compact**<span offset-key="bc33566253704b16bef5bc7b6b805f58:1">: Because of its size, it can be sent through an URL, POST parameter, or inside an HTTP header. Additionally, due to its size its transmission is fast.</span></span>

-   <img src="data:image/svg+xml;base64," class="r-1nf4jbm r-1vzi8xi" />

    <span key="a3af6f7e01ee491ca7ac9cd268d040cb">**Self-contained**<span offset-key="a3af6f7e01ee491ca7ac9cd268d040cb:1">: The payload contains all the required information about the user, to avoid querying the database more than once.</span></span>

<span key="af18782e6532408b92d6e34799fb21b5"><span offset-key="af18782e6532408b92d6e34799fb21b5:0">Interested in getting up-to-speed with JWTs as soon as possible? </span></span><a href="https://auth0.com/resources/ebooks/jwt-handbook" class="css-4rbku5 css-1dbjc4n r-1loqt21 r-1471scf r-1otgn73 r-1i6wzkk r-lrvibr"><span data-key="2c3f0c33c3f7478d8f39ec3eddbcb7a9" data-rnw-int-class="nearest_257-1697_259-1698-237__"><span data-key="bddf2b24daa74d59a0950a29ce5f68b6"><span data-offset-key="bddf2b24daa74d59a0950a29ce5f68b6:0">DOWNLOAD THE FREE EBOOK</span></span></span></a><span key="1f54986332da4489abab32dfab083a22"><span offset-key="1f54986332da4489abab32dfab083a22:0"><span slate-zero-width="z">â€‹</span></span></span>

<span key="f6d7d30ddcd54351879385f6192f381a"><span offset-key="f6d7d30ddcd54351879385f6192f381a:0">ipad pro handbook</span></span>

## 

<span key="e5162704d60247369702c6823a7c67d0"><span offset-key="e5162704d60247369702c6823a7c67d0:0">WHEN SHOULD YOU USE JSON WEB TOKENS?</span></span>

<span key="a98ef12113e145f2b04a7abcf1cbc0fb"><span offset-key="a98ef12113e145f2b04a7abcf1cbc0fb:0">These are some scenarios where JSON Web Tokens are useful:</span></span>

-   <img src="data:image/svg+xml;base64," class="r-1nf4jbm r-1vzi8xi" />

    <span key="88ff7dcfccdb4321ab2205353a2bfb73">**Authentication**<span offset-key="88ff7dcfccdb4321ab2205353a2bfb73:1">: This is the typical scenario for using JWT, once the user is logged in, each subsequent request will include the JWT, allowing the user to access routes, services, and resources that are permitted with that token. Single Sign On is a feature that widely uses JWT nowadays, because of its small overhead and its ability to be easily used among systems of different domains.</span></span>

-   <img src="data:image/svg+xml;base64," class="r-1nf4jbm r-1vzi8xi" />

    <span key="9cc424da668741fba8d7a3106393c09d">**Information Exchange**<span offset-key="9cc424da668741fba8d7a3106393c09d:1">: JWTs are a good way of securely transmitting information between parties, because as they can be signed, for example using a public/private key pair, you can be sure that the sender is who they say they are. Additionally, as the signature is calculated using the header and the payload, you can also verify that the content hasnâ€™t changed.</span></span>

## 

<span key="efb2384e6c084012906a10c2ccb3d723"><span offset-key="efb2384e6c084012906a10c2ccb3d723:0">WHICH IS THE JSON WEB TOKEN STRUCTURE?</span></span>

<span key="49d7e584caf748bf80215523bd5baf60"><span offset-key="49d7e584caf748bf80215523bd5baf60:0">JWTs consist of three parts separated by dots (</span>`.`<span offset-key="49d7e584caf748bf80215523bd5baf60:2">), which are:</span></span>

-   <img src="data:image/svg+xml;base64," class="r-1nf4jbm r-1vzi8xi" />

    <span key="4723869005af46a7af65123920ebf02a">**Header**</span>

-   <img src="data:image/svg+xml;base64," class="r-1nf4jbm r-1vzi8xi" />

    <span key="18d084651cb1496ea72439ebbb141761">**Payload**</span>

-   <img src="data:image/svg+xml;base64," class="r-1nf4jbm r-1vzi8xi" />

    <span key="6f109de0b80b4967b9c66ddc8d08db38">**Signature**</span>

<span key="5651816a43564efc9fcbfeccf8a6d884"><span offset-key="5651816a43564efc9fcbfeccf8a6d884:0">Therefore, a JWT typically looks like the following.</span></span>

<span key="29045ec057634cf1b4d41491c07b6270">`xxxxx.yyyyy.zzzzz`</span>

<span key="44b86ecee99a4941b07e6eaad66a2135"><span offset-key="44b86ecee99a4941b07e6eaad66a2135:0">Letâ€™s break down the different parts.</span></span>

### 

<span key="48923f209ca84839b17f7807a96a80eb"><span offset-key="48923f209ca84839b17f7807a96a80eb:0">Header</span></span>

<span key="46cb59c26fc14a05b7b5c3f7729faab8"><span offset-key="46cb59c26fc14a05b7b5c3f7729faab8:0">The header </span>*typically*<span offset-key="46cb59c26fc14a05b7b5c3f7729faab8:2"> consists of two parts: the type of the token, which is JWT, and the hashing algorithm such as HMAC SHA256 or RSA.</span></span>

<span key="9c39037cf80e4743acbb8ddf21e237a1"><span offset-key="9c39037cf80e4743acbb8ddf21e237a1:0">For example:</span></span>

1

<span key="2ab817662d1045f2ab0dba9baf03c19e"><span offset-key="2ab817662d1045f2ab0dba9baf03c19e:0">{</span></span>

2

<span key="e607446ae3594a7b89d4bfdcd5e576fa"><span offset-key="e607446ae3594a7b89d4bfdcd5e576fa:0"> "alg": "HS256",</span></span>

3

<span key="eb89d8992dff4b39ba3389b2c7a6f591"><span offset-key="eb89d8992dff4b39ba3389b2c7a6f591:0"> "typ": "JWT"</span></span>

4

<span key="d44fd6e13cb94025b3ce9b44e0073ebd"><span offset-key="d44fd6e13cb94025b3ce9b44e0073ebd:0">}</span></span>

<img src="data:image/svg+xml;base64," class="r-h7gdob r-10ptun7 r-1vzi8xi" />

Copied!

<span key="0b527dad65e64bcdbdc543540572fd80"><span offset-key="0b527dad65e64bcdbdc543540572fd80:0">Then, this JSON is </span>**Base64Url**<span offset-key="0b527dad65e64bcdbdc543540572fd80:2"> encoded to form the first part of the JWT.</span></span>

### 

<span key="20332313abfb4daa9a8b9dd258a12ae3"><span offset-key="20332313abfb4daa9a8b9dd258a12ae3:0">Payload</span></span>

<span key="1f8609e1239e4a7b9a4731e48f50f745"><span offset-key="1f8609e1239e4a7b9a4731e48f50f745:0">The second part of the token is the payload, which contains the claims. Claims are statements about an entity (typically, the user) and additional metadata. There are three types of claims: </span>*reserved*<span offset-key="1f8609e1239e4a7b9a4731e48f50f745:2">, </span>*public*<span offset-key="1f8609e1239e4a7b9a4731e48f50f745:4">, and </span>*private*<span offset-key="1f8609e1239e4a7b9a4731e48f50f745:6"> claims.</span></span>

-   <img src="data:image/svg+xml;base64," class="r-1nf4jbm r-1vzi8xi" />

    <span key="9de9f41400fd46a1b3a169e0e48bbbd3"><span offset-key="9de9f41400fd46a1b3a169e0e48bbbd3:0"><span slate-zero-width="n">â€‹</span></span></span>

    -   <img src="data:image/svg+xml;base64," class="r-1nf4jbm r-1vzi8xi" />

        <span key="90ad8f2d78634fb8bdcdfd1ec14e5075">**Reserved claims**<span offset-key="90ad8f2d78634fb8bdcdfd1ec14e5075:1">: These are a set of predefined claims, which are not mandatory but recommended, thought to provide a set of useful, interoperable claims. Some of them are: </span>**iss**<span offset-key="90ad8f2d78634fb8bdcdfd1ec14e5075:3"> (issuer), </span>**exp**<span offset-key="90ad8f2d78634fb8bdcdfd1ec14e5075:5"> (expiration time), </span>**sub**<span offset-key="90ad8f2d78634fb8bdcdfd1ec14e5075:7"> (subject), </span>**aud**<span offset-key="90ad8f2d78634fb8bdcdfd1ec14e5075:9"> (audience), among others.</span></span>

> <span key="2b785eeda7154176ae1821fa85e6d0c5"><span offset-key="2b785eeda7154176ae1821fa85e6d0c5:0">Notice that the claim names are only three characters long as JWT is meant to be compact.</span></span>

-   <img src="data:image/svg+xml;base64," class="r-1nf4jbm r-1vzi8xi" />

    <span key="a0b2a7de07924c83a0b8a2df81117987">**Public claims**<span offset-key="a0b2a7de07924c83a0b8a2df81117987:1">: These can be defined at will by those using JWTs. But to avoid collisions they should be defined in the IANA JSON Web Token Registry or be defined as a URI that contains a collision resistant namespace.</span></span>

-   <img src="data:image/svg+xml;base64," class="r-1nf4jbm r-1vzi8xi" />

    <span key="a3de4e0fa50944a2bc84cb1d2ef2fc85">**Private claims**<span offset-key="a3de4e0fa50944a2bc84cb1d2ef2fc85:1">: These are the custom claims created to share information between parties that agree on using them.</span></span>

<span key="913c1ce3110c42478521a4725b081c98"><span offset-key="913c1ce3110c42478521a4725b081c98:0">An example of payload could be:</span></span>

1

<span key="9ae064822c2544619e62a6d7f745f596"><span offset-key="9ae064822c2544619e62a6d7f745f596:0">{</span></span>

2

<span key="94837c784d2644e2b22e78f214a999c9"><span offset-key="94837c784d2644e2b22e78f214a999c9:0"> "sub": "1234567890",</span></span>

3

<span key="4c0ad96712d7486fba5b00071b9975be"><span offset-key="4c0ad96712d7486fba5b00071b9975be:0"> "name": "John Doe",</span></span>

4

<span key="c07bc61bc16449a49caf18bdbcf3565b"><span offset-key="c07bc61bc16449a49caf18bdbcf3565b:0"> "admin": true</span></span>

5

<span key="ce4ad338e8bf4c12bf62fcc7c6778b57"><span offset-key="ce4ad338e8bf4c12bf62fcc7c6778b57:0">}</span></span>

<img src="data:image/svg+xml;base64," class="r-h7gdob r-10ptun7 r-1vzi8xi" />

Copied!

<span key="8cd5c2cf9c8649539f69b8fe383f405f"><span offset-key="8cd5c2cf9c8649539f69b8fe383f405f:0">The payload is then </span>**Base64Url**<span offset-key="8cd5c2cf9c8649539f69b8fe383f405f:2"> encoded to form the second part of the JWT.</span></span>

### 

<span key="eba7134fdbc943878ce5e74011058f64"><span offset-key="eba7134fdbc943878ce5e74011058f64:0">Signature</span></span>

<span key="109bb3b1475e4c53b86f4a79acb98089"><span offset-key="109bb3b1475e4c53b86f4a79acb98089:0">To create the signature part you have to take the encoded header, the encoded payload, a secret, the algorithm specified in the header, and sign that.</span></span>

<span key="0be6c5f45fc64fcb9715d9501c00945e"><span offset-key="0be6c5f45fc64fcb9715d9501c00945e:0">For example if you want to use the HMAC SHA256 algorithm, the signature will be created in the following way.</span></span>

1

<span key="67dfedecea7a48d8814187a58f401fa4"><span offset-key="67dfedecea7a48d8814187a58f401fa4:0">HMACSHA256(</span></span>

2

<span key="4c496b850edf4ae9aeb2430e9650ff40"><span offset-key="4c496b850edf4ae9aeb2430e9650ff40:0"> base64UrlEncode(header) + "." +</span></span>

3

<span key="f9d41168375e4fb2983f8d7f288ec8ca"><span offset-key="f9d41168375e4fb2983f8d7f288ec8ca:0"> base64UrlEncode(payload),</span></span>

4

<span key="86d735194d1440f083e86c2579b4c880"><span offset-key="86d735194d1440f083e86c2579b4c880:0"> secret)</span></span>

<img src="data:image/svg+xml;base64," class="r-h7gdob r-10ptun7 r-1vzi8xi" />

Copied!

<span key="baa92edaaa3b44f59788cd92110e0a6f"><span offset-key="baa92edaaa3b44f59788cd92110e0a6f:0">The signature is used to verify that the sender of the JWT is who it says it is and to ensure that the message wasâ€™t changed in the way.</span></span>

### 

<span key="350b8de328d3471f8352254c0ccaba4d"><span offset-key="350b8de328d3471f8352254c0ccaba4d:0">Putting all together</span></span>

<span key="ca6b0b755448457fbd50026234e61a16"><span offset-key="ca6b0b755448457fbd50026234e61a16:0">The output is three Base64 strings separated by dots that can be easily passed in HTML and HTTP environments, while being more compact compared to XML-based standards such as SAML.</span></span>

<span key="23740f5115a44d488e2c48650fd47304"><span offset-key="23740f5115a44d488e2c48650fd47304:0">The following shows a JWT that has the previous header and payload encoded and it is signed with a secret.</span></span>

<span key="ed6c8292430d498cb3475e3d8c738e71"><span offset-key="ed6c8292430d498cb3475e3d8c738e71:0">An encoded JWT</span></span>

<span key="10a892840b3f49d3b41574501526ca8a"><span offset-key="10a892840b3f49d3b41574501526ca8a:0">You can browse to </span></span><a href="http://jwt.io" class="css-4rbku5 css-1dbjc4n r-1loqt21 r-1471scf r-1otgn73 r-1i6wzkk r-lrvibr"><span data-key="185c47ead7364d61bd990609c23379c2" data-rnw-int-class="nearest_257-1697_259-1698-237__"><span data-key="47e004dd81114248a9d1a2eb513fb764"><span data-offset-key="47e004dd81114248a9d1a2eb513fb764:0">jwt.io</span></span></span></a><span key="3ba02c55cf214ff09d5b7d2c7e37b825"><span offset-key="3ba02c55cf214ff09d5b7d2c7e37b825:0"> where you can play with a JWT and put these concepts in practice. </span></span><a href="http://jwt.io" class="css-4rbku5 css-1dbjc4n r-1loqt21 r-1471scf r-1otgn73 r-1i6wzkk r-lrvibr"><span data-key="0ea398869f974b21a35d925b475ef464" data-rnw-int-class="nearest_257-1697_259-1698-237__"><span data-key="8e11f7a4e55c473ebc78a29e9ca5dc4c"><span data-offset-key="8e11f7a4e55c473ebc78a29e9ca5dc4c:0">jwt.io</span></span></span></a><span key="a11eeb7a10de4d08a476728e7d54da23"><span offset-key="a11eeb7a10de4d08a476728e7d54da23:0"> allows you to decode, verify and generate JWT.</span></span>

## 

<span key="a579c27a15544ae0907e8ac04c2e6ca1"><span offset-key="a579c27a15544ae0907e8ac04c2e6ca1:0">HOW JSON WEB TOKENS WORK?</span></span>

<span key="15fa334230e1445e8690be076c624504"><span offset-key="15fa334230e1445e8690be076c624504:0">In authentication, when the user successfully logs in using their credentials, a JSON Web Token will be returned. Since tokens are credentials, great care must be taken to prevent security issues. In general, you should not keep tokens longer than required.</span></span>

<span key="bb158b9be791492f8faf21f4d7d26ef5"><span offset-key="bb158b9be791492f8faf21f4d7d26ef5:0">You also </span></span><a href="https://cheatsheetseries.owasp.org/cheatsheets/HTML5_Security_Cheat_Sheet.html#local-storage" class="css-4rbku5 css-1dbjc4n r-1loqt21 r-1471scf r-1otgn73 r-1i6wzkk r-lrvibr"><span data-key="bdfeb8e97cd84df0913969045bcc41ca" data-rnw-int-class="nearest_257-1697_259-1698-237__"><span data-key="ddbb72daf78b4096a246149f782d5f90"><span data-offset-key="ddbb72daf78b4096a246149f782d5f90:0">should not store sensitive session data in browser storage due to lack of security</span></span></span></a><span key="0ecc026c8cd24bf0bad414f3a876a0cc"><span offset-key="0ecc026c8cd24bf0bad414f3a876a0cc:0">.</span></span>

<span key="1b335003b09f44e696508b3c45fb8b27"><span offset-key="1b335003b09f44e696508b3c45fb8b27:0">Whenever the user wants to access a protected route, it should send the JWT, typically in the </span>**Authorization**<span offset-key="1b335003b09f44e696508b3c45fb8b27:2"> header using the </span>**Bearer**<span offset-key="1b335003b09f44e696508b3c45fb8b27:4"> schema. Therefore the content of the header should look like the following.</span></span>

<span key="854ae029427c47a283a91d52cc9fd998">`Authorization: Bearer <token>`</span>

<span key="6b4abc9ed0504e5fa699067040301f52"><span offset-key="6b4abc9ed0504e5fa699067040301f52:0">This is a stateless authentication mechanism as the user state is never saved in the server memory. The serverâ€™s protected routes will check for a valid JWT in the Authorization header, and if there is, the user will be allowed. As JWTs are self-contained, all the necessary information is there, reducing the need of going back and forward to the database.</span></span>

<span key="9296343688c9484cbabfba7535b44f46"><span offset-key="9296343688c9484cbabfba7535b44f46:0">This allows to fully rely on data APIs that are stateless and even make requests to downstream services. It doesnâ€™t matter which domains are serving your APIs, as Cross-Origin Resource Sharing (CORS) wonâ€™t be an issue as it doesnâ€™t use cookies. </span></span>

## 

<span key="4f89c7ecd4cc41fea6f3a508e52b8ab5"><span offset-key="4f89c7ecd4cc41fea6f3a508e52b8ab5:0">WHY SHOULD YOU USE JSON WEB TOKENS?</span></span>

<span key="07fda08da9464f4fafd016566add753d"><span offset-key="07fda08da9464f4fafd016566add753d:0">Letâ€™s talk about the benefits of </span>**JSON Web Tokens (JWT)**<span offset-key="07fda08da9464f4fafd016566add753d:2"> comparing it to </span>**Simple Web Tokens (SWT)**<span offset-key="07fda08da9464f4fafd016566add753d:4"> and </span>**Security Assertion Markup Language Tokens (SAML)**<span offset-key="07fda08da9464f4fafd016566add753d:6">.</span></span>

<span key="a98302c4dd8b479297b15eaabea16902"><span offset-key="a98302c4dd8b479297b15eaabea16902:0">As JSON is less verbose than XML, when it is encoded its size is also smaller; making JWT more compact than SAML. This makes JWT a good choice to be passed in HTML and HTTP environments.</span></span>

<span key="65afc0f85a6b4eb08e3002c905c69b41"><span offset-key="65afc0f85a6b4eb08e3002c905c69b41:0">Security-wise, SWT can only be symmetric signed by a shared secret using the HMAC algorithm. While JWT and SAML tokens can also use a public/private key pair in the form of a X.509 certificate to sign them. However, signing XML with XML Digital Signature without introducing obscure security holes is very difficult compared to the simplicity of signing JSON.</span></span>

<span key="47ce9204854743ff8751e95fd8869c20"><span offset-key="47ce9204854743ff8751e95fd8869c20:0">JSON parsers are common in most programming languages, because they map directly to objects, conversely XML doesnâ€™t have a natural document-to-object mapping. This makes it easier to work with JWT than SAML assertions.</span></span>

<span key="7e180bf75a0a4377bef4e55d827ea559"><span offset-key="7e180bf75a0a4377bef4e55d827ea559:0">Regarding usage, JWT is used at an Internet scale. This highlights the ease of client side processing of JWTs on multiple platforms, especially, mobile. </span></span>

## 

<span key="8ff90e224920463f8dac4606bfd85a0f"><span offset-key="8ff90e224920463f8dac4606bfd85a0f:0">HOW WE USE JSON WEB TOKENS IN AUTH0?</span></span>

<span key="48d9c09646e748a493bae1497cad39c7"><span offset-key="48d9c09646e748a493bae1497cad39c7:0">In Auth0, we issue JWTs as a result of the authentication process. When the user logs in using Auth0, a JWT is created, signed, and sent to the user. Auth0 supports signing JWT with both HMAC and RSA algorithms. This token will be then used to authenticate and authorize with APIs which will grant access to their protected routes and resources.</span></span>

<span key="bf65ede33784421c9ef3fc3ce4c770b4"><span offset-key="bf65ede33784421c9ef3fc3ce4c770b4:0">We also use JWTs to perform authentication and authorization in Auth0â€™s API v2, replacing the traditional usage of regular opaque API keys. Regarding authorization, JSON Web Tokens allow granular security, that is the ability to specify a particular set of permissions in the token, which improves debuggability.</span></span>

<a href="ds-ap.html" class="css-4rbku5 css-1dbjc4n r-1awozwy r-14lw9ot r-190qawg r-z2wwpe r-rs99b7 r-4dj0k7 r-1loqt21 r-1quu1zo r-1ro0kt6 r-18u37iz r-16y2uox r-1wbh5a2 r-nsbfu8 r-1otgn73 r-1i6wzkk r-lrvibr"></a>
